examples.term: fun {Î±} {motive} {a b} hâ‚ hâ‚‚ => hâ‚ â–¸ hâ‚‚
examples.name: Eq.subst
examples.doc:
The substitution principle for equality. If `a = b ` and `P a` holds,
then `P b` also holds. We conventionally use the name `motive` for `P` here,
so that you can specify it explicitly using e.g.
`Eq.subst (motive := fun x => x < 5)` if it is not otherwise inferred correctly.

This theorem is the underlying mechanism behind the `rw` tactic, which is
essentially a fancy algorithm for finding good `motive` arguments to usefully
apply this theorem to replace occurrences of `a` with `b` in the goal or
hypotheses.

For more information: [Equality](https://leanprover.github.io/theorem_proving_in_lean4/quantifiers_and_equality.html#equality)

examples.term: fun {Î±} {a b} h => h â–¸ rfl
examples.name: Eq.symm
examples.doc:
Equality is symmetric: if `a = b` then `b = a`.

Because this is in the `Eq` namespace, if you have a variable `h : a = b`,
`h.symm` can be used as shorthand for `Eq.symm h` as a proof of `b = a`.

For more information: [Equality](https://leanprover.github.io/theorem_proving_in_lean4/quantifiers_and_equality.html#equality)

examples.term: PUnit.{1}
examples.name: Unit
examples.doc:
The unit type, the canonical type with one element, named `unit` or `()`.
In other words, it describes only a single value, which consists of said constructor applied
to no arguments whatsoever.
The `Unit` type is similar to `void` in languages derived from C.

`Unit` is actually defined as `PUnit.{0}` where `PUnit` is the universe
polymorphic version. The `Unit` should be preferred over `PUnit` where possible to avoid
unnecessary universe parameters.

In functional programming, `Unit` is the return type of things that "return
nothing", since a type with one element conveys no additional information.
When programming with monads, the type `m Unit` represents an action that has
some side effects but does not return a value, while `m Î±` would be an action
that has side effects and returns a value of type `Î±`.

examples.term: ULift.{u, 0} â„•
examples.name: FintypeCat.Skeleton
examples.doc:
The "standard" skeleton for `FintypeCat`. This is the full subcategory of `FintypeCat`
spanned by objects of the form `ULift (Fin n)` for `n : â„•`. We parameterize the objects
of `Fintype.Skeleton` directly as `ULift â„•`, as the type `ULift (Fin m) â‰ƒ ULift (Fin n)`
is nonempty if and only if `n = m`. Specifying universes, `Skeleton : Type u` is a small
skeletal category equivalent to `Fintype.{u}`.

examples.term: âˆ€ (Î± : Type (max u v)), Small.{v, max u v} Î±
examples.name: UnivLE
examples.doc:
A class expressing a universe inequality. `UnivLE.{u, v}` expresses that `u â‰¤ v`.

There are (at least) two plausible definitions for `u â‰¤ v`:
* strong: `âˆ€ Î± : Type max u v, Small.{v} Î±`
* weak: `âˆ€ Î± : Type u, Small.{v} Î±`

The weak definition has the advantage of being transitive.
However only under the strong definition do we have `Small.{v} ((Î± : Type u) â†’ (Î² : Type v))`,
which is essential for proving that `Type v` has `Type u`-indexed limits when `u â‰¤ v`.

The strong definition implies the weaker definition (see below),
but we can not prove the reverse implication.
This is because in Lean's type theory, while `max u v` is at least at big as `u` and `v`,
it could be bigger than both!

and `(hn h).elim` will prove anything.

examples.term: fun m k => PNat.modDivAux k (â†‘m % â†‘k) (â†‘m / â†‘k)
examples.name: PNat.modDiv
examples.doc:
`mod_div m k = (m % k, m / k)`.
We define `m % k` and `m / k` in the same way as for `â„•`
except that when `m = n * k` we take `m % k = k` and
`m / k = n - 1`.  This ensures that `m % k` is always positive
and `m = (m % k) + k * (m / k)` in all cases.  Later we
define a function `div_exact` which gives the usual `m / k`
in the case where `k` divides `m`.

see `PadicInt.norm_sub_modPart`.
It is the unique non-negative integer that is `< p` with this property.

(Note that this definition assumes `r : â„š`.
See `PadicInt.zmodRepr` for a version that takes values in `â„•`
and works for arbitrary `x : â„¤_[p]`.)

If `M` multiplicatively acts on `Î±`, then `DomMulAct M` acts on `Î± â†’ Î²` as well as some

examples.name: Monoid.Foldl
examples.doc:
For a list, foldl f x [yâ‚€,yâ‚] reduces as follows:

```
calc  foldl f x [yâ‚€,yâ‚]
    = foldl f (f x yâ‚€) [yâ‚]      : rfl
... = foldl f (f (f x yâ‚€) yâ‚) [] : rfl
... = f (f x yâ‚€) yâ‚              : rfl
```
with
```
f : Î± â†’ Î² â†’ Î±
x : Î±
[yâ‚€,yâ‚] : List Î²
```

We can view the above as a composition of functions:
```
... = f (f x yâ‚€) yâ‚              : rfl
... = flip f yâ‚ (flip f yâ‚€ x)    : rfl
... = (flip f yâ‚ âˆ˜ flip f yâ‚€) x  : rfl
```

We can use traverse and const to construct this composition:
```
calc   const.run (traverse (Î» y, const.mk' (flip f y)) [yâ‚€,yâ‚]) x
     = const.run ((::) <$> const.mk' (flip f yâ‚€) <*> traverse (Î» y, const.mk' (flip f y)) [yâ‚]) x
...  = const.run ((::) <$> const.mk' (flip f yâ‚€) <*>
         ( (::) <$> const.mk' (flip f yâ‚) <*> traverse (Î» y, const.mk' (flip f y)) [] )) x
...  = const.run ((::) <$> const.mk' (flip f yâ‚€) <*>
         ( (::) <$> const.mk' (flip f yâ‚) <*> pure [] )) x
...  = const.run ( ((::) <$> const.mk' (flip f yâ‚) <*> pure []) âˆ˜
         ((::) <$> const.mk' (flip f yâ‚€)) ) x
...  = const.run ( const.mk' (flip f yâ‚) âˆ˜ const.mk' (flip f yâ‚€) ) x
...  = const.run ( flip f yâ‚ âˆ˜ flip f yâ‚€ ) x
...  = f (f x yâ‚€) yâ‚
```

And this is how `const` turns a monoid into an applicative functor and
how the monoid of endofunctions define `Foldl`.

examples.name: MeasureTheory.Measure.haar.chaar
examples.doc:
This is the "limit" of `prehaar Kâ‚€ U K` as `U` becomes a smaller and smaller open
neighborhood of `(1 : G)`. More precisely, it is defined to be an arbitrary element
in the intersection of all the sets `clPrehaar Kâ‚€ V` in `haarProduct Kâ‚€`.
This is roughly equal to the Haar measure on compact sets,
but it can differ slightly. We do know that
`haarMeasure Kâ‚€ (interior K) â‰¤ chaar Kâ‚€ K â‰¤ haarMeasure Kâ‚€ K`.

examples.term: âˆ€ (Î± : Type (max u v)), Small.{v, max u v} Î±
examples.name: UnivLE
examples.doc:
A class expressing a universe inequality. `UnivLE.{u, v}` expresses that `u â‰¤ v`.

There are (at least) two plausible definitions for `u â‰¤ v`:
* strong: `âˆ€ Î± : Type max u v, Small.{v} Î±`
* weak: `âˆ€ Î± : Type u, Small.{v} Î±`

The weak definition has the advantage of being transitive.
However only under the strong definition do we have `Small.{v} ((Î± : Type u) â†’ (Î² : Type v))`,
which is essential for proving that `Type v` has `Type u`-indexed limits when `u â‰¤ v`.

The strong definition implies the weaker definition (see below),
but we can not prove the reverse implication.
This is because in Lean's type theory, while `max u v` is at least at big as `u` and `v`,
it could be bigger than both!

examples.name: Filter.IsCobounded
examples.doc:
`IsCobounded (â‰º) f` states that the filter `f` does not tend to infinity w.r.t. `â‰º`. This is
also called frequently bounded. Will be usually instantiated with `â‰¤` or `â‰¥`.

There is a subtlety in this definition: we want `f.IsCobounded` to hold for any `f` in the case of
complete lattices. This will be relevant to deduce theorems on complete lattices from their
versions on conditionally complete lattices with additional assumptions. We have to be careful in
the edge case of the trivial filter containing the empty set: the other natural definition
  `Â¬ âˆ€ a, âˆ€á¶  n in f, a â‰¤ n`
would not work as well in this case.

`expNegInvGlue` is the real function given by `x â†¦ exp (-1/x)` for `x > 0` and `0`
for `x â‰¤ 0`. It is a basic building block to construct smooth partitions of unity. Its main property
is that it vanishes for `x â‰¤ 0`, it is positive for `x > 0`, and the junction between the two
behaviors is flat enough to retain smoothness. The fact that this function is `C^âˆž` is proved in
`expNegInvGlue.contDiff `.

Average value of an `â„â‰¥0âˆž`-valued function `f` w.r.t. a measure `Î¼`, notation: `â¨â» x, f x âˆ‚Î¼`.
It is defined as `Î¼ univâ»Â¹ * âˆ«â» x, f x âˆ‚Î¼`, so it is equal to zero if `Î¼` is an infinite measure. If

average w.r.t. the volume, one can omit `âˆ‚volume`.

examples.name: MeasureTheory.lintegral_withDensity_eq_lintegral_mul
examples.doc:
This is Exercise 1.2.1 from [tao2010]. It allows you to express integration of a measurable
function with respect to `(Î¼.withDensity f)` as an integral with respect to `Î¼`, called the base
measure. `Î¼` is often the Lebesgue measure, and in this circumstance `f` is the probability density
function, and `(Î¼.withDensity f)` represents any continuous random variable as a
probability measure, such as the uniform distribution between 0 and 1, the Gaussian distribution,
the exponential distribution, the Beta distribution, or the Cauchy distribution (see Section 2.4
of [wasserman2004]). Thus, this method shows how to one can calculate expectations, variances,
and other moments as a function of the probability density function.

  decide
    (Std.RBSet.size c.history â‰¤
      1 + Std.RBSet.size (Std.RBSet.union (Std.RBSet.filter c.implicit fun x => decide (x â‰¥ elimedGE)) c.effective))
examples.name: Linarith.PComp.maybeMinimal
examples.doc:
Any comparison whose history is not minimal is redundant,
and need not be included in the new set of comparisons.
`elimedGE : â„•` is a natural number such that all variables with index â‰¥ `elimedGE` have been
removed from the system.

This test is an overapproximation to minimality. It gives necessary but not sufficient conditions.
If the history of `c` is minimal, then `c.maybeMinimal` is true,
but `c.maybeMinimal` may also be true for some `c` with non-minimal history.
Thus, if `c.maybeMinimal` is false, `c` is known not to be minimal and must be redundant.
See https://doi.org/10.1016/B978-0-444-88771-9.50019-2 (Theorem 13).
The condition described there considers only implicitly eliminated variables that have been
officially eliminated from the system. This is not the case for every implicitly eliminated
variable. Consider eliminating `z` from `{x + y + z < 0, x - y - z < 0}`. The result is the set
`{2*x < 0}`; `y` is implicitly but not officially eliminated.

This implementation of Fourier-Motzkin elimination processes variables in decreasing order of
indices. Immediately after a step that eliminates variable `k`, variable `k'` has been eliminated
iff `k' â‰¥ k`. Thus we can compute the intersection of officially and implicitly eliminated variables
by taking the set of implicitly eliminated variables with indices â‰¥ `elimedGE`.

examples.name: levenshtein
examples.doc:
`levenshtein C xs ys` computes the Levenshtein distance
(using the cost functions provided by a `C : Cost Î± Î² Î´`)
from the list `xs` to the list `ys`.

Note that if the cost functions do not satisfy the inequalities
* `C.delete a + C.insert b â‰¥ C.substitute a b`
* `C.substitute a b + C.substitute b c â‰¥ C.substitute a c`
(or if any values are negative)
then the edit distance calculated here may not agree with the general
geodesic distance on the edit graph.

fun {Î¹} {X} [TopologicalSpace X] {s} f =>
  PartitionOfUnity.mk s (fun i => ContinuousMap.mk (BumpCovering.toPOUFun f i))
    (_ : LocallyFinite fun i => Function.support â†‘((fun i => ContinuousMap.mk (BumpCovering.toPOUFun f i)) i))
    (_ : âˆ€ (i : Î¹) (x : X), 0 â‰¤ â†‘(â†‘f i) x * âˆá¶  (j : Î¹) (_ : WellOrderingRel j i), (1 - â†‘(â†‘f j) x))
    (_ : âˆ€ (x : X), x âˆˆ s â†’ âˆ‘á¶  (i : Î¹), â†‘((fun i => ContinuousMap.mk (BumpCovering.toPOUFun f i)) i) x = 1)

examples.name: BumpCovering.toPartitionOfUnity
examples.doc:
The partition of unity defined by a `BumpCovering`.

The partition of unity is given by the formula `g i x = f i x * âˆá¶  j < i, (1 - f j x)`. In other
words, `g i x = âˆá¶  j < i, (1 - f j x) - âˆá¶  j â‰¤ i, (1 - f j x)`, so
`âˆ‘á¶  i, g i x = 1 - âˆá¶  j, (1 - f j x)`. If `x âˆˆ s`, then one of `f j x` equals one, hence the product
of `1 - f j x` vanishes, and `âˆ‘á¶  i, g i x = 1`.

In order to avoid an assumption `LinearOrder Î¹`, we use `WellOrderingRel` instead of `(<)`.

examples.name: CategoryTheory.bijection
examples.doc:
We construct a bijection between morphisms `L(A â¨¯ B) âŸ¶ X` and morphisms `LA â¨¯ LB âŸ¶ X`.
This bijection has two key properties:
* It is natural in `X`: See `bijection_natural`.
* When `X = LA â¨¯ LB`, then the backwards direction sends the identity morphism to the product
  comparison morphism: See `bijection_symm_apply_id`.

Together these help show that `L` preserves binary products. This should be considered
*internal implementation* towards `preservesBinaryProductsOfExponentialIdeal`.

  PartitionOfUnity.mk s (fun i => ContinuousMap.mk (BumpCovering.toPOUFun f i))
    (_ : LocallyFinite fun i => Function.support â†‘((fun i => ContinuousMap.mk (BumpCovering.toPOUFun f i)) i))
    (_ : âˆ€ (i : Î¹) (x : X), 0 â‰¤ â†‘(â†‘f i) x * âˆá¶  (j : Î¹) (_ : WellOrderingRel j i), (1 - â†‘(â†‘f j) x))
    (_ : âˆ€ (x : X), x âˆˆ s â†’ âˆ‘á¶  (i : Î¹), â†‘((fun i => ContinuousMap.mk (BumpCovering.toPOUFun f i)) i) x = 1)

examples.name: BumpCovering.toPartitionOfUnity
examples.doc:
The partition of unity defined by a `BumpCovering`.

The partition of unity is given by the formula `g i x = f i x * âˆá¶  j < i, (1 - f j x)`. In other
words, `g i x = âˆá¶  j < i, (1 - f j x) - âˆá¶  j â‰¤ i, (1 - f j x)`, so
`âˆ‘á¶  i, g i x = 1 - âˆá¶  j, (1 - f j x)`. If `x âˆˆ s`, then one of `f j x` equals one, hence the product
of `1 - f j x` vanishes, and `âˆ‘á¶  i, g i x = 1`.

In order to avoid an assumption `LinearOrder Î¹`, we use `WellOrderingRel` instead of `(<)`.

examples.name: BumpCovering.toPOUFun
examples.doc:
Partition of unity defined by a `BumpCovering`. We use this auxiliary definition to prove some
properties of the new family of functions before bundling it into a `PartitionOfUnity`. Do not use
this definition, use `BumpCovering.toPartitionOfUnity` instead.

The partition of unity is given by the formula `g i x = f i x * âˆá¶  j < i, (1 - f j x)`. In other
words, `g i x = âˆá¶  j < i, (1 - f j x) - âˆá¶  j â‰¤ i, (1 - f j x)`, so
`âˆ‘á¶  i, g i x = 1 - âˆá¶  j, (1 - f j x)`. If `x âˆˆ s`, then one of `f j x` equals one, hence the product
of `1 - f j x` vanishes, and `âˆ‘á¶  i, g i x = 1`.

In order to avoid an assumption `LinearOrder Î¹`, we use `WellOrderingRel` instead of `(<)`.

fun Î¾ =>
  let f := fun q => (q.num, q.den);
  let s := {q | |Î¾ - q| < 1 / â†‘q.den ^ 2};
  Eq.mpr
    (id
      ((let_fun this := rfl;
        this) â–¸
        Eq.refl (Set.Finite {q | |Î¾ - q| < 1 / â†‘q.den ^ 2})))
    (let_fun hinj := fun â¦ƒa bâ¦„ hab =>
      Eq.mpr (id (Eq.symm (Rat.num_div_den a) â–¸ Eq.refl (a = b)))
        (Eq.mpr (id (Eq.symm (Rat.num_div_den b) â–¸ Eq.refl (â†‘a.num / â†‘a.den = b)))
          (Eq.mpr
            (id
              ((Eq.mp Mathlib.NumberTheory.DiophantineApproximation._auxLemma.4 hab).left â–¸
                Eq.refl (â†‘a.num / â†‘a.den = â†‘b.num / â†‘b.den)))
            (Eq.mpr
              (id
                ((Eq.mp Mathlib.NumberTheory.DiophantineApproximation._auxLemma.4 hab).right â–¸
                  Eq.refl (â†‘b.num / â†‘a.den = â†‘b.num / â†‘b.den)))
              (Eq.refl (â†‘b.num / â†‘b.den)))));
    let_fun H := fun â¦ƒxyâ¦„ hxy =>
      Exists.casesOn
        (Eq.mp
          (Eq.trans
            (Eq.trans (congrArg (Membership.mem xy) (Set.image_congr fun a a_1 => Eq.refl (a.num, a.den)))
              (Mathlib.NumberTheory.DiophantineApproximation._auxLemma.5 (fun a => (a.num, a.den))
                {q | |Î¾ - q| < 1 / â†‘q.den ^ 2} xy))
            (congrArg Exists
              (funext fun x =>
                congrFun (congrArg And Mathlib.NumberTheory.DiophantineApproximation._auxLemma.6)
                  ((x.num, x.den) = xy))))
          hxy)
        fun q h =>
        And.casesOn h fun hqâ‚ hqâ‚‚ =>
          And.casesOn (Rat.den_le_and_le_num_le_of_sub_lt_one_div_den_sq hqâ‚) fun hd hn =>
            Eq.mpr
              (id
                (Eq.trans Mathlib.NumberTheory.DiophantineApproximation._auxLemma.7
                  (congrArg Exists (funext fun i => Mathlib.NumberTheory.DiophantineApproximation._auxLemma.7))))
              (Exists.intro q.den
                (Exists.intro (Iff.mpr Set.mem_Ioc { left := Rat.pos q, right := hd })
                  (Eq.mpr
                    (id
                      (Eq.trans
                        (Eq.trans (congrArg (Membership.mem xy) Set.prod_singleton)
                          (Mathlib.NumberTheory.DiophantineApproximation._auxLemma.5 (fun a => (a, q.den))
                            (Set.Icc (âŒˆÎ¾ * â†‘q.denâŒ‰ - 1) (âŒŠÎ¾ * â†‘q.denâŒ‹ + 1)) xy))
                        (congrArg Exists
                          (funext fun x =>
                            congrFun (congrArg And Mathlib.NumberTheory.DiophantineApproximation._auxLemma.8)
                              ((x, q.den) = xy)))))
                    (Exists.intro q.num { left := hn, right := hqâ‚‚ }))));
    Set.Finite.of_finite_image
      (Set.Finite.subset
        (Set.Finite.biUnion (Set.finite_Ioc 0 Î¾.den) fun x x_1 =>
          Set.Finite.prod (Set.finite_Icc (âŒˆÎ¾ * â†‘xâŒ‰ - 1) (âŒŠÎ¾ * â†‘xâŒ‹ + 1)) (Set.finite_singleton x))
        H)
      (Set.injOn_of_injective hinj s))

examples.term: fun R [AddMonoid R] R' [CommMonoid R'] => Multiplicative R â†’* R'
examples.name: AddChar
examples.doc:
Define `AddChar R R'` as `(Multiplicative R) â†’* R'`.
The definition works for an additive monoid `R` and a monoid `R'`,
but we will restrict to the case that both are commutative rings below.
We assume right away that `R'` is commutative, so that `AddChar R R'` carries
a structure of commutative monoid.
The trivial additive character (sending everything to `1`) is `(1 : AddChar R R').`

examples.name: LiouvilleWith
examples.doc:
We say that a real number `x` is a Liouville number with exponent `p : â„` if there exists a real
number `C` such that for infinitely many denominators `n` there exists a numerator `m` such that
`x â‰  m / n` and `|x - m / n| < C / n ^ p`.

A number is a Liouville number in the sense of `Liouville` if it is `LiouvilleWith` any real
exponent.

The set of cluster points of a filter is closed. In particular, the set of limit points
of a sequence is closed.

  Eq.mpr
    (id
      (Eq.symm (propext closure_subset_iff_isClosed) â–¸
        Eq.refl (IsClosed s â†” âˆ€ (x : Î±), (âˆƒá¶  (y : Î±) in nhds x, y âˆˆ s) â†’ x âˆˆ s)))
    (forall_congr' fun x =>

A set `s` is closed iff for every point `x`, if there is a point `y` close to `x` that belongs
to `s` then `x` is in `s`.

fun {Î±} [TopologicalSpace Î±] x C =>
  of_eq_true
    (Eq.trans
      (congrFun
        (congrArg Iff
          (Eq.trans (Eq.trans (Mathlib.Topology.Basic._auxLemma.46 x C) Mathlib.Topology.Basic._auxLemma.47)
            (congrFun
              (congrArg Filter.Frequently
                (funext fun y =>
                  Eq.trans
                    (Eq.trans (Mathlib.Data.Set.Basic._auxLemma.84 y)
                      (congrArg (And (y âˆˆ C)) (congrArg Not Mathlib.Data.Set.Basic._auxLemma.44)))
                    Mathlib.Topology.Basic._auxLemma.48))
              (nhds x))))
        (âˆƒá¶  (y : Î±) in nhds x, Â¬y = x âˆ§ y âˆˆ C))
      (iff_self (âˆƒá¶  (y : Î±) in nhds x, Â¬y = x âˆ§ y âˆˆ C)))
examples.name: accPt_iff_frequently
examples.doc:
`x` is an accumulation point of a set `C` iff
there are points near `x` in `C` and different from `x`.

examples.term:
fun {Ï„} {Î±} {Î²} [TopologicalSpace Î²] f Ï• s y =>
  Eq.mpr
    (id
      (congrFun (congrArg Iff (Mathlib.Dynamics.OmegaLimit._auxLemma.4 f Ï• s y))
        (âˆ€ (n : Set Î²), n âˆˆ nhds y â†’ âˆƒá¶  (t : Ï„) in f, Set.Nonempty (Ï• t '' s âˆ© n))))
    (of_eq_true
      (Eq.trans
        (congrArg (Iff (âˆ€ (n : Set Î²), n âˆˆ nhds y â†’ âˆƒá¶  (t : Ï„) in f, Set.Nonempty (s âˆ© Ï• t â»Â¹' n)))
          (forall_congr fun n =>
            implies_congr (Eq.refl (n âˆˆ nhds y))
              (congrFun (congrArg Filter.Frequently (funext fun t => Mathlib.Dynamics.OmegaLimit._auxLemma.5)) f)))
        (iff_self (âˆ€ (n : Set Î²), n âˆˆ nhds y â†’ âˆƒá¶  (t : Ï„) in f, Set.Nonempty (s âˆ© Ï• t â»Â¹' n)))))
examples.name: mem_omegaLimit_iff_frequentlyâ‚‚

An element `y` is in the Ï‰-limit set of `s` w.r.t. `f` if the
forward images of `s` frequently (w.r.t. `f`) intersect arbitrary

examples.name: List.cyclicPermutations
examples.doc:
List of all cyclic permutations of `l`.
The `cyclicPermutations` of a nonempty list `l` will always contain `List.length l` elements.
This implies that under certain conditions, there are duplicates in `List.cyclicPermutations l`.
The `n`th entry is equal to `l.rotate n`, proven in `List.nthLe_cyclicPermutations`.
The proof that every cyclic permutant of `l` is in the list is `List.mem_cyclicPermutations_iff`.

     cyclicPermutations [1, 2, 3, 2, 4] =
       [[1, 2, 3, 2, 4], [2, 3, 2, 4, 1], [3, 2, 4, 1, 2],
        [2, 4, 1, 2, 3], [4, 1, 2, 3, 2]]

  match oâ‚ with
  | (ONote.zero, 0) => if oâ‚‚ = 0 then 1 else 0
  | (ONote.zero, 1) => 1
  | (ONote.zero, Nat.succ m) =>
    match ONote.split' oâ‚‚ with
    | (b', k) => ONote.oadd b' (Nat.succPNat m ^ k) 0
  | (a@h:(ONote.oadd a0 a_1 a_2), m) =>
    match ONote.split oâ‚‚ with
    | (b, 0) => ONote.oadd (a0 * b) 1 0
    | (b, Nat.succ k) =>

      ONote.scale (eb + ONote.mulNat a0 k) a + ONote.opowAux eb a0 (ONote.mulNat a m) k m

                        (congrArg (Int.ModEq â†‘p)
                          (congr
                            (congrArg HAdd.hAdd (congrFun (congrArg HPow.hPow (Int.coe_natAbs (ZMod.valMinAbs a))) 2))
                            (congrFun (congrArg HPow.hPow (Int.coe_natAbs (ZMod.valMinAbs b))) 2)))
                        x))
                    (Eq.mpr
                      (id
                        (sq_abs (ZMod.valMinAbs a) â–¸
                          Eq.refl (|ZMod.valMinAbs a| ^ 2 + |ZMod.valMinAbs b| ^ 2 â‰¡ x [ZMOD â†‘p])))
                      (Eq.mpr
                        (id
                          (sq_abs (ZMod.valMinAbs b) â–¸
                            Eq.refl (ZMod.valMinAbs a ^ 2 + |ZMod.valMinAbs b| ^ 2 â‰¡ x [ZMOD â†‘p])))
                        (Eq.mpr
                          (id
                            (Eq.symm
                                (propext
                                  (ZMod.int_cast_eq_int_cast_iff (ZMod.valMinAbs a ^ 2 + ZMod.valMinAbs b ^ 2) x p)) â–¸
                              Eq.refl (ZMod.valMinAbs a ^ 2 + ZMod.valMinAbs b ^ 2 â‰¡ x [ZMOD â†‘p])))
                          (cast
                            (Eq.trans
                              (Eq.trans
                                (congrFun
                                  (congrArg Eq
                                    (Eq.trans
                                      (congr
                                        (congrArg HAdd.hAdd
                                          (Mathlib.Algebra.GroupPower.Lemmas._auxLemma.12 (ZMod.valMinAbs a) 2))
                                        (Mathlib.Algebra.GroupPower.Lemmas._auxLemma.12 (ZMod.valMinAbs b) 2))
                                      (Mathlib.Data.Int.Cast.Basic._auxLemma.7 (ZMod.valMinAbs a ^ 2)
                                        (ZMod.valMinAbs b ^ 2))))
                                  â†‘x)
                                (congrFun
                                  (congrArg Eq
                                    (Eq.trans
                                      (Eq.trans (Int.cast_add (ZMod.valMinAbs a ^ 2) (ZMod.valMinAbs b ^ 2))
                                        (congr
                                          (congrArg HAdd.hAdd
                                            (Eq.trans (Int.cast_pow (ZMod.valMinAbs a) 2)
                                              (congrFun (congrArg HPow.hPow (ZMod.coe_valMinAbs a)) 2)))
                                          (Eq.trans (Int.cast_pow (ZMod.valMinAbs b) 2)
                                            (congrFun (congrArg HPow.hPow (ZMod.coe_valMinAbs b)) 2))))
                                      (Eq.symm
                                        (Eq.trans (Int.cast_add (ZMod.valMinAbs a ^ 2) (ZMod.valMinAbs b ^ 2))
                                          (congr
                                            (congrArg HAdd.hAdd
                                              (Eq.trans (Int.cast_pow (ZMod.valMinAbs a) 2)
                                                (congrFun (congrArg HPow.hPow (ZMod.coe_valMinAbs a)) 2)))
                                            (Eq.trans (Int.cast_pow (ZMod.valMinAbs b) 2)
                                              (congrFun (congrArg HPow.hPow (ZMod.coe_valMinAbs b)) 2)))))))
                                  â†‘x))
                              (Eq.symm
                                (congrFun
                                  (congrArg Eq
                                    (Eq.trans
                                      (Eq.trans (Int.cast_add (ZMod.valMinAbs a ^ 2) (ZMod.valMinAbs b ^ 2))
                                        (congr
                                          (congrArg HAdd.hAdd
                                            (Eq.trans (Int.cast_pow (ZMod.valMinAbs a) 2)
                                              (congrFun (congrArg HPow.hPow (ZMod.coe_valMinAbs a)) 2)))
                                          (Eq.trans (Int.cast_pow (ZMod.valMinAbs b) 2)
                                            (congrFun (congrArg HPow.hPow (ZMod.coe_valMinAbs b)) 2))))
                                      (Eq.symm
                                        (Eq.trans (Int.cast_add (ZMod.valMinAbs a ^ 2) (ZMod.valMinAbs b ^ 2))
                                          (congr
                                            (congrArg HAdd.hAdd
                                              (Eq.trans (Int.cast_pow (ZMod.valMinAbs a) 2)
                                                (congrFun (congrArg HPow.hPow (ZMod.coe_valMinAbs a)) 2)))
                                            (Eq.trans (Int.cast_pow (ZMod.valMinAbs b) 2)
                                              (congrFun (congrArg HPow.hPow (ZMod.coe_valMinAbs b)) 2)))))))
                                  â†‘x)))
                            (Eq.mp (Eq.symm (ZMod.coe_valMinAbs b) â–¸ Eq.refl (â†‘(ZMod.valMinAbs a) ^ 2 + b ^ 2 = â†‘x))
                              (Eq.mp (Eq.symm (ZMod.coe_valMinAbs a) â–¸ Eq.refl (a ^ 2 + b ^ 2 = â†‘x)) hx)))))) } })

fun {R} [CommRing R] {p q} hmonic hdegree =>
  Mathlib.Tactic.Nontriviality.subsingleton_or_nontrivial_elim
    (fun [anonymous] =>
      of_eq_true
        (Eq.trans
          (congr
            (congrArg Eq
              (Polynomial.Monic.leadingCoeff
                (of_eq_true (Mathlib.Data.Polynomial.Degree.Definitions._auxLemma.1 (p /â‚˜ q)))))
            (Polynomial.Monic.leadingCoeff (of_eq_true (Mathlib.Data.Polynomial.Degree.Definitions._auxLemma.1 p))))
          (eq_self 1)))
    fun [anonymous] =>
    let_fun h :=
      Eq.mpr
        (id
          (Eq.trans
            (Eq.trans
              (congrFun
                (congrArg Ne
                  (Eq.trans
                    (congrFun (congrArg HMul.hMul (Polynomial.Monic.leadingCoeff hmonic))
                      (Polynomial.leadingCoeff (p /â‚˜ q)))
                    (one_mul (Polynomial.leadingCoeff (p /â‚˜ q)))))
                0)
              (congrArg Not
                (Eq.trans Mathlib.Data.Polynomial.Degree.Definitions._auxLemma.10
                  ((fun x_0 => propext ((fun x_0 => Polynomial.divByMonic_eq_zero_iff hmonic) x_0)) p))))
            Mathlib.Init.Order.Defs._auxLemma.1))
        hdegree;
    Eq.mpr
      (id
        (Eq.symm (Polynomial.modByMonic_add_div p hmonic) â–¸
          Eq.refl (Polynomial.leadingCoeff (p /â‚˜ q) = Polynomial.leadingCoeff p)))
      (Eq.mpr
        (id
          (Polynomial.leadingCoeff_add_of_degree_lt
              (Eq.mpr
                (id
                  (Polynomial.degree_mul' h â–¸ Eq.refl (Polynomial.degree (p %â‚˜ q) < Polynomial.degree (q * (p /â‚˜ q)))))
                (Eq.mpr
                  (id
                    (Polynomial.degree_add_divByMonic hmonic hdegree â–¸
                      Eq.refl (Polynomial.degree (p %â‚˜ q) < Polynomial.degree q + Polynomial.degree (p /â‚˜ q))))
                  (LT.lt.trans_le (Polynomial.degree_modByMonic_lt p hmonic) hdegree))) â–¸
            Eq.refl (Polynomial.leadingCoeff (p /â‚˜ q) = Polynomial.leadingCoeff (p %â‚˜ q + q * (p /â‚˜ q)))))
        (Eq.mpr
          (id
            (Polynomial.leadingCoeff_monic_mul hmonic â–¸
              Eq.refl (Polynomial.leadingCoeff (p /â‚˜ q) = Polynomial.leadingCoeff (q * (p /â‚˜ q)))))
          (Eq.refl (Polynomial.leadingCoeff (p /â‚˜ q)))))

examples.term:
fun {R} [CommRing R] {n} hpos =>
  Mathlib.Tactic.Nontriviality.subsingleton_or_nontrivial_elim
    (fun [anonymous] =>
      of_eq_true
        (Mathlib.Logic.Unique._auxLemma.1 (Polynomial.cyclotomic n R)
          ((Polynomial.X ^ n - 1) /â‚˜ Finset.prod (Nat.properDivisors n) fun i => Polynomial.cyclotomic i R)))
    fun [anonymous] =>
    Eq.mpr
      (id
        (Eq.symm (Polynomial.prod_cyclotomic_eq_X_pow_sub_one hpos R) â–¸
          Eq.refl
            (Polynomial.cyclotomic n R =
              (Polynomial.X ^ n - 1) /â‚˜ Finset.prod (Nat.properDivisors n) fun i => Polynomial.cyclotomic i R)))
      (Eq.mpr
        (id
          (Eq.symm (Nat.cons_self_properDivisors (LT.lt.ne' hpos)) â–¸
            Eq.refl
              (Polynomial.cyclotomic n R =
                (Finset.prod (Nat.divisors n) fun i => Polynomial.cyclotomic i R) /â‚˜
                  Finset.prod (Nat.properDivisors n) fun i => Polynomial.cyclotomic i R)))
        (Eq.mpr
          (id
            (Finset.prod_cons Nat.properDivisors.not_self_mem â–¸
              Eq.refl
                (Polynomial.cyclotomic n R =
                  (Finset.prod (Finset.cons n (Nat.properDivisors n) Nat.properDivisors.not_self_mem) fun i =>
                      Polynomial.cyclotomic i R) /â‚˜
                    Finset.prod (Nat.properDivisors n) fun i => Polynomial.cyclotomic i R)))
          (let_fun prod_monic :=
            Polynomial.monic_prod_of_monic (Nat.properDivisors n) (fun i => Polynomial.cyclotomic i R) fun i a =>
              Polynomial.cyclotomic.monic i R;
          Eq.mpr
            (id
              ((Polynomial.div_modByMonic_unique (Polynomial.cyclotomic n R) 0 prod_monic
                    (Eq.mpr
                      (id
                        (congrFun
                          (congrArg And
                            (congrFun
                              (congrArg Eq
                                (zero_add
                                  ((Finset.prod (Nat.properDivisors n) fun i => Polynomial.cyclotomic i R) *
                                    Polynomial.cyclotomic n R)))
                              (Polynomial.cyclotomic n R *
                                Finset.prod (Nat.properDivisors n) fun i => Polynomial.cyclotomic i R)))
                          (âŠ¥ <
                            Polynomial.degree (Finset.prod (Nat.properDivisors n) fun i => Polynomial.cyclotomic i R))))
                      {
                        left :=
                          Eq.mpr
                            (id
                              (mul_comm (Finset.prod (Nat.properDivisors n) fun i => Polynomial.cyclotomic i R)
                                  (Polynomial.cyclotomic n R) â–¸
                                Eq.refl
                                  ((Finset.prod (Nat.properDivisors n) fun i => Polynomial.cyclotomic i R) *
                                      Polynomial.cyclotomic n R =
                                    Polynomial.cyclotomic n R *
                                      Finset.prod (Nat.properDivisors n) fun i => Polynomial.cyclotomic i R)))
                            (Eq.refl
                              (Polynomial.cyclotomic n R *
                                Finset.prod (Nat.properDivisors n) fun i => Polynomial.cyclotomic i R)),
                        right :=
                          Eq.mpr
                            (id
                              (propext bot_lt_iff_ne_bot â–¸
                                Eq.refl
                                  (âŠ¥ <
                                    Polynomial.degree
                                      (Finset.prod (Nat.properDivisors n) fun i => Polynomial.cyclotomic i R))))
                            fun h => Polynomial.Monic.ne_zero prod_monic (Iff.mp Polynomial.degree_eq_bot h) })).left â–¸
                Eq.refl
                  (Polynomial.cyclotomic n R =
                    (Polynomial.cyclotomic n R *
                        Finset.prod (Nat.properDivisors n) fun x => Polynomial.cyclotomic x R) /â‚˜
                      Finset.prod (Nat.properDivisors n) fun i => Polynomial.cyclotomic i R)))
            (Eq.refl (Polynomial.cyclotomic n R)))))

fun {K} [CommRing K] [IsDomain K] {Î¶} {n} hpos h =>
  Eq.mpr
    (id
      (Eq.symm (Polynomial.prod_cyclotomic'_eq_X_pow_sub_one hpos h) â–¸
        Eq.refl
          (Polynomial.cyclotomic' n K =
            (Polynomial.X ^ n - 1) /â‚˜ Finset.prod (Nat.properDivisors n) fun i => Polynomial.cyclotomic' i K)))
    (Eq.mpr
      (id
        (Eq.symm (Nat.cons_self_properDivisors (LT.lt.ne' hpos)) â–¸
          Eq.refl
            (Polynomial.cyclotomic' n K =
              (Finset.prod (Nat.divisors n) fun i => Polynomial.cyclotomic' i K) /â‚˜
                Finset.prod (Nat.properDivisors n) fun i => Polynomial.cyclotomic' i K)))
      (Eq.mpr
        (id
          (Finset.prod_cons Nat.properDivisors.not_self_mem â–¸
            Eq.refl
              (Polynomial.cyclotomic' n K =
                (Finset.prod (Finset.cons n (Nat.properDivisors n) Nat.properDivisors.not_self_mem) fun i =>
                    Polynomial.cyclotomic' i K) /â‚˜
                  Finset.prod (Nat.properDivisors n) fun i => Polynomial.cyclotomic' i K)))
        (let_fun prod_monic :=
          Polynomial.monic_prod_of_monic (Nat.properDivisors n) (fun i => Polynomial.cyclotomic' i K) fun i a =>
            Polynomial.cyclotomic'.monic i K;
        Eq.mpr
          (id
            ((Polynomial.div_modByMonic_unique (Polynomial.cyclotomic' n K) 0 prod_monic
                  (Eq.mpr
                    (id
                      (congrFun
                        (congrArg And
                          (congrFun
                            (congrArg Eq
                              (zero_add
                                ((Finset.prod (Nat.properDivisors n) fun i => Polynomial.cyclotomic' i K) *
                                  Polynomial.cyclotomic' n K)))
                            (Polynomial.cyclotomic' n K *
                              Finset.prod (Nat.properDivisors n) fun i => Polynomial.cyclotomic' i K)))
                        (âŠ¥ <
                          Polynomial.degree (Finset.prod (Nat.properDivisors n) fun i => Polynomial.cyclotomic' i K))))
                    {
                      left :=
                        Eq.mpr
                          (id
                            (mul_comm (Finset.prod (Nat.properDivisors n) fun i => Polynomial.cyclotomic' i K)
                                (Polynomial.cyclotomic' n K) â–¸
                              Eq.refl
                                ((Finset.prod (Nat.properDivisors n) fun i => Polynomial.cyclotomic' i K) *
                                    Polynomial.cyclotomic' n K =
                                  Polynomial.cyclotomic' n K *
                                    Finset.prod (Nat.properDivisors n) fun i => Polynomial.cyclotomic' i K)))
                          (Eq.refl
                            (Polynomial.cyclotomic' n K *
                              Finset.prod (Nat.properDivisors n) fun i => Polynomial.cyclotomic' i K)),
                      right :=
                        Eq.mpr
                          (id
                            (propext bot_lt_iff_ne_bot â–¸
                              Eq.refl
                                (âŠ¥ <
                                  Polynomial.degree
                                    (Finset.prod (Nat.properDivisors n) fun i => Polynomial.cyclotomic' i K))))
                          fun h => Polynomial.Monic.ne_zero prod_monic (Iff.mp Polynomial.degree_eq_bot h) })).left â–¸
              Eq.refl
                (Polynomial.cyclotomic' n K =
                  (Polynomial.cyclotomic' n K *
                      Finset.prod (Nat.properDivisors n) fun x => Polynomial.cyclotomic' x K) /â‚˜
                    Finset.prod (Nat.properDivisors n) fun i => Polynomial.cyclotomic' i K)))
          (Eq.refl (Polynomial.cyclotomic' n K)))))

      ((L : Xâ‚ âŠž Xâ‚‚ â‰… Xâ‚ âŠž Xâ‚‚) Ã—'
          (R : Yâ‚ âŠž Yâ‚‚ â‰… Yâ‚ âŠž Yâ‚‚) Ã—'

                  (CategoryTheory.CategoryStruct.comp
                    (CategoryTheory.Biprod.ofComponents
                      (CategoryTheory.CategoryStruct.comp CategoryTheory.Limits.biprod.inl
                        (CategoryTheory.CategoryStruct.comp f CategoryTheory.Limits.biprod.fst))
                      (CategoryTheory.CategoryStruct.comp CategoryTheory.Limits.biprod.inl
                        (CategoryTheory.CategoryStruct.comp f CategoryTheory.Limits.biprod.snd))
                      (CategoryTheory.CategoryStruct.comp CategoryTheory.Limits.biprod.inr
                        (CategoryTheory.CategoryStruct.comp f CategoryTheory.Limits.biprod.fst))
                      (CategoryTheory.CategoryStruct.comp CategoryTheory.Limits.biprod.inr
                        (CategoryTheory.CategoryStruct.comp f CategoryTheory.Limits.biprod.snd)))
                    R.hom) =
                CategoryTheory.Limits.biprod.map
                  (CategoryTheory.CategoryStruct.comp CategoryTheory.Limits.biprod.inl
                    (CategoryTheory.CategoryStruct.comp f CategoryTheory.Limits.biprod.fst))

        ((L : Xâ‚ âŠž Xâ‚‚ â‰… Xâ‚ âŠž Xâ‚‚) Ã—'
          (R : Yâ‚ âŠž Yâ‚‚ â‰… Yâ‚ âŠž Yâ‚‚) Ã—'
            (gâ‚‚â‚‚ : Xâ‚‚ âŸ¶ Yâ‚‚) Ã—'

                CategoryTheory.Limits.biprod.map
                  (CategoryTheory.CategoryStruct.comp CategoryTheory.Limits.biprod.inl

examples.name: CategoryTheory.Biprod.gaussian
examples.doc:
If `f` is a morphism `Xâ‚ âŠž Xâ‚‚ âŸ¶ Yâ‚ âŠž Yâ‚‚` whose `Xâ‚ âŸ¶ Yâ‚` entry is an isomorphism,
then we can construct isomorphisms `L : Xâ‚ âŠž Xâ‚‚ â‰… Xâ‚ âŠž Xâ‚‚` and `R : Yâ‚ âŠž Yâ‚‚ â‰… Yâ‚ âŠž Yâ‚‚`
so that `L.hom â‰« g â‰« R.hom` is diagonal (with `Xâ‚ âŸ¶ Yâ‚` component still `f`),
via Gaussian elimination.

                      (Polynomial.leadingCoeff (p /â‚˜ q)))

                  ((fun x_0 => propext ((fun x_0 => Polynomial.divByMonic_eq_zero_iff hmonic) x_0)) p))))
            Mathlib.Init.Order.Defs._auxLemma.1))

                (Eq.mpr

            Eq.refl (Polynomial.leadingCoeff (p /â‚˜ q) = Polynomial.leadingCoeff (p %â‚˜ q + q * (p /â‚˜ q)))))

fun {f} {a b} hfi hpos hab =>
  let_fun hsupp := fun x hx =>
    { left := Iff.mpr Function.mem_support (LT.lt.ne' (hpos x hx)), right := Set.Ioo_subset_Ioc_self hx };
  let_fun hâ‚€ :=
    Eq.mpr

            (MeasureTheory.Measure.ae (MeasureTheory.Measure.restrict MeasureTheory.volume (Î™ a b))) 0 f â–¸
          Eq.refl (0 â‰¤á¶ [MeasureTheory.Measure.ae (MeasureTheory.Measure.restrict MeasureTheory.volume (Î™ a b))] f)))
      (Eq.mpr
        (id
          (Set.uIoc_of_le (LT.lt.le hab) â–¸
            Eq.refl (âˆ€áµ (x : â„) âˆ‚MeasureTheory.Measure.restrict MeasureTheory.volume (Î™ a b), OfNat.ofNat 0 x â‰¤ f x)))
        (MeasureTheory.ae_restrict_of_ae_eq_of_ae_restrict MeasureTheory.Ioo_ae_eq_Ioc
          (Iff.mpr (MeasureTheory.ae_restrict_iff' measurableSet_Ioo)
            (MeasureTheory.ae_of_all MeasureTheory.volume fun x hx => LT.lt.le (hpos x hx)))));

    (id
      (propext (intervalIntegral.integral_pos_iff_support_of_nonneg_ae' hâ‚€ hfi) â–¸ Eq.refl (0 < âˆ« (x : â„) in a..b, f x)))
    { left := hab,

          (MeasureTheory.measure_mono hsupp) }

    (Eq.mpr (id (Eq.symm (Zsqrtd.norm_eq_mul_conj a) â–¸ Eq.refl (Zsqrtd.norm a = 1 â†” a * star a = 1)))
      (Eq.mpr

examples.name: Ordnode.ofAscListAuxâ‚
examples.doc:
Auxiliary definition for `ofAscList`.

**Note:** This function is defined by well founded recursion, so it will probably not compute
in the kernel, meaning that you probably can't prove things like
`ofAscList [1, 2, 3] = {1, 2, 3}` by `rfl`.
This implementation is optimized for VM evaluation.

Show that the exponential of the terminal object is isomorphic to itself, i.e. `X^1 â‰… X`.

The typeclass argument is explicit: any instance can be used.

Given a natural isomorphism `i â‹™ exp A â‹™ leftAdjoint i â‹™ i â‰… i â‹™ exp A`, we can show `i`
is an exponential ideal.

examples.name: CategoryTheory.exponentialIdealReflective
examples.doc:
If `D` is a reflective subcategory, the property of being an exponential ideal is equivalent to
the presence of a natural isomorphism `i â‹™ exp A â‹™ leftAdjoint i â‹™ i â‰… i â‹™ exp A`, that is:
`(A âŸ¹ iB) â‰… i L (A âŸ¹ iB)`, naturally in `B`.
The converse is given in `ExponentialIdeal.mk_of_iso`.

    [CategoryTheory.Limits.HasFiniteProducts D] [CategoryTheory.ExponentialIdeal i] A B X =>
  Trans.trans
    (Trans.trans

                (Trans.trans
                  (Trans.trans
                    (Trans.trans
                      (CategoryTheory.Adjunction.homEquiv (CategoryTheory.Adjunction.ofRightAdjoint i) (A â¨¯ B) X)
                      (CategoryTheory.Iso.homCongr (CategoryTheory.Limits.prod.braiding A B)
                        (CategoryTheory.Iso.refl (i.obj X))))
                    (CategoryTheory.Adjunction.homEquiv (CategoryTheory.exp.adjunction B) A (i.obj X)))
                  (CategoryTheory.unitCompPartialBijective A (_ : (B âŸ¹ i.obj X) âˆˆ CategoryTheory.Functor.essImage i)))
                (CategoryTheory.Adjunction.homEquiv (CategoryTheory.exp.adjunction B)
                    (i.obj ((CategoryTheory.leftAdjoint i).obj A)) (i.obj X)).symm)
              (CategoryTheory.Iso.homCongr
                (CategoryTheory.Limits.prod.braiding B (i.obj ((CategoryTheory.leftAdjoint i).obj A)))
                (CategoryTheory.Iso.refl (i.obj X))))

          (CategoryTheory.unitCompPartialBijective B
            (_ : (i.obj ((CategoryTheory.leftAdjoint i).obj A) âŸ¹ i.obj X) âˆˆ CategoryTheory.Functor.essImage i)))
        (CategoryTheory.Adjunction.homEquiv
            (CategoryTheory.exp.adjunction (i.obj ((CategoryTheory.leftAdjoint i).obj A)))
            (i.obj ((CategoryTheory.leftAdjoint i).obj B)) (i.obj X)).symm)

    (CategoryTheory.equivOfFullyFaithful i).symm
examples.name: CategoryTheory.bijection
examples.doc:
We construct a bijection between morphisms `L(A â¨¯ B) âŸ¶ X` and morphisms `LA â¨¯ LB âŸ¶ X`.
This bijection has two key properties:
* It is natural in `X`: See `bijection_natural`.
* When `X = LA â¨¯ LB`, then the backwards direction sends the identity morphism to the product
  comparison morphism: See `bijection_symm_apply_id`.

Together these help show that `L` preserves binary products. This should be considered
*internal implementation* towards `preservesBinaryProductsOfExponentialIdeal`.

examples.name: CategoryTheory.closedOfHasLeftDual
examples.doc:
If `Y` has a left dual `á˜Y`, then it is a closed object, with the internal hom functor `Y âŸ¶[C] -`
given by left tensoring by `á˜Y`.
This has to be a definition rather than an instance to avoid diamonds, for example between
`category_theory.monoidal_closed.functor_closed` and
`category_theory.monoidal.functor_has_left_dual`. Moreover, in concrete applications there is often
a more useful definition of the internal hom object than `á˜Y âŠ— X`, in which case the closed
structure shouldn't come from `has_left_dual` (e.g. in the category `FinVect k`, it is more
convenient to define the internal hom as `Y â†’â‚—[k] X` rather than `á˜Y âŠ— X` even though these are
naturally isomorphic).

  CategoryTheory.CategoryStruct.comp (CategoryTheory.MonoidalCategory.leftUnitor á˜Y).inv
    (CategoryTheory.CategoryStruct.comp
      (CategoryTheory.MonoidalCategory.tensorHom (Î·_ (á˜X) X) (CategoryTheory.CategoryStruct.id á˜Y))
      (CategoryTheory.CategoryStruct.comp
        (CategoryTheory.MonoidalCategory.tensorHom
          (CategoryTheory.MonoidalCategory.tensorHom (CategoryTheory.CategoryStruct.id á˜X) f)
          (CategoryTheory.CategoryStruct.id á˜Y))
        (CategoryTheory.CategoryStruct.comp (CategoryTheory.MonoidalCategory.associator (á˜X) Y á˜Y).hom
          (CategoryTheory.CategoryStruct.comp
            (CategoryTheory.MonoidalCategory.tensorHom (CategoryTheory.CategoryStruct.id á˜X) (Îµ_ (á˜Y) Y))
            (CategoryTheory.MonoidalCategory.rightUnitor á˜X).hom))))

a.e. on a set `t` of finite measure, then either this function is a.e. equal to its average value on

examples.doc:
If an integrable function `f : Î± â†’ E` takes values in a convex set `s` and for some set `t` of
positive measure, the average value of `f` over `t` belongs to the interior of `s`, then the average
of `f` over the whole space belongs to the interior of `s`.

examples.doc:
**Jensen's inequality**: if a function `g : E â†’ â„` is concave and continuous on a convex closed
set `s`, `Î¼` is a finite non-zero measure on `Î±`, and `f : Î± â†’ E` is a function sending
`Î¼`-a.e. points of a set `t` to `s`, then the average value of `g âˆ˜ f` over `t` is less than or
equal to the value of `g` at the average value of `f` over `t` provided that both `f` and `g âˆ˜ f`
are integrable.

    (List.Chain.cons (fun h => LE.le.trans (pure_le_nhds x) h)

            (List.Chain.cons

      And.casesOn a fun hy ho =>
        Exists.casesOn

            (Iff.mpr

                (Eq.mpr
                  (id
                    (Filter.principal_singleton x â–¸
                      Eq.refl (ClusterPt y (Filter.principal {x}) â†” ClusterPt y (pure x))))
                  Iff.rfl))
              h)
            s ho hy)
          fun z h_1 =>
          And.casesOn h_1 fun hxs right =>
            Eq.ndrec (motive := fun x =>
              (x â¤³ y â†’ pure x â‰¤ nhds y) â†’
                (pure x â‰¤ nhds y â†’ âˆ€ (s : Set X), IsOpen s â†’ y âˆˆ s â†’ x âˆˆ s) â†’
                  ((âˆ€ (s : Set X), IsOpen s â†’ y âˆˆ s â†’ x âˆˆ s) â†’ âˆ€ (s : Set X), IsClosed s â†’ x âˆˆ s â†’ y âˆˆ s) â†’
                    ((âˆ€ (s : Set X), IsClosed s â†’ x âˆˆ s â†’ y âˆˆ s) â†’ y âˆˆ closure {x}) â†’
                      (closure {y} âŠ† closure {x} â†” y âˆˆ closure {x}) â†’
                        (y âˆˆ closure {x} â†” ClusterPt y (pure x)) â†’ y âˆˆ closure {x} â†’ s âˆˆ nhds x)
              (fun tfae_1_to_2 tfae_2_to_3 tfae_3_to_4 tfae_4_to_5 tfae_6_iff_5 tfae_5_iff_7 h =>
                IsOpen.mem_nhds ho hxs)
              right (LE.le.trans (pure_le_nhds x)) (fun h s hso hy => h (IsOpen.mem_nhds hso hy))
              (fun h s hsc hx => of_not_not fun hy => h sá¶œ IsClosed.isOpen_compl hy hx)
              (fun h => h (closure {x}) isClosed_closure (subset_closure (Set.mem_singleton x)))
              (Iff.trans (IsClosed.closure_subset_iff isClosed_closure) Set.singleton_subset_iff)
              (Eq.mpr (id (propext mem_closure_iff_clusterPt â–¸ Eq.refl (y âˆˆ closure {x} â†” ClusterPt y (pure x))))
                (Eq.mpr
                  (id
                    (Filter.principal_singleton x â–¸

              (Iff.mpr
                (Eq.mpr (id (propext mem_closure_iff_clusterPt â–¸ Eq.refl (y âˆˆ closure {x} â†” ClusterPt y (pure x))))
                  (Eq.mpr

examples.term:
fun x className args => do
  let __do_lift â† Lean.getEnv
  let __discr : Option Lean.ConstantInfo := Lean.Environment.find? __do_lift className
  match __discr with
    | some classExpr =>
      let arity := Lean.Expr.forallArity (Lean.ConstantInfo.type classExpr);
      if (arity == Array.size args) = true then pure (Array.map some args)
      else
        if (Array.size args == 1) = true then pure (mkArray arity (some args[0]!))
        else
          Lean.throwError
            (Lean.toMessageData "initialize_simps_projections cannot automatically find arguments for class " ++
                Lean.toMessageData className ++
              Lean.toMessageData "")
    | x =>
      Lean.throwError (Lean.toMessageData "no such class " ++ Lean.toMessageData className ++ Lean.toMessageData "")

fun declNames => do
  let ctx â† Lean.Elab.Deriving.mkContext "toExpr" declNames[0]!
  let __do_lift â† Mathlib.Deriving.ToExpr.mkMutualBlock ctx
  let __do_lift_1 â† Mathlib.Deriving.ToExpr.mkInstanceCmds ctx declNames
  let cmds : Array Lean.Syntax := #[__do_lift] ++ Lean.TSyntaxArray.raw __do_lift_1
  let cls : Lean.Name := `Elab.Deriving.toExpr
  let __do_lift â† Lean.isTracingEnabledFor cls
  let __do_jp : Unit â†’ Lean.Elab.TermElabM (Array Lean.Syntax) := fun y => pure cmds
  if __do_lift = true then do
      let y â† Lean.addTrace cls (Lean.toMessageData "\n" ++ Lean.toMessageData cmds ++ Lean.toMessageData "")
      __do_jp y
    else do
      let y â† pure PUnit.unit
      __do_jp y

examples.name: Complex.cderiv

A circle integral which coincides with `deriv f z` whenever one can apply the Cauchy formula for
the derivative. It is useful in the proof that locally uniform limits of holomorphic functions are
holomorphic, because it depends continuously on `f` for the uniform topology.

    ((2 * â†‘Real.pi * Complex.I)â»Â¹ â€¢ âˆ® (z : â„‚) in C(c, R), (z - c)â»Â¹ ^ n â€¢ (z - c)â»Â¹ â€¢ f z)
examples.name: cauchyPowerSeries
examples.doc:
The power series that is equal to
$\sum_{n=0}^{\infty} \oint_{|z-c|=R} \left(\frac{w-c}{z - c}\right)^n \frac{1}{z-c}f(z)\,dz$ at
`w - c`. The coefficients of this power series depend only on `f âˆ˜ circleMap c R`, and the power
series converges to `f w` if `f` is differentiable on the closed ball `Metric.closedBall c R` and
`w` belongs to the corresponding open ball. For any circle integrable function `f`, this power
series converges to the Cauchy integral for `f`.

For any circle integrable function `f`, the power series `cauchyPowerSeries f c R`, `R > 0`,
converges to the Cauchy integral `(2 * Ï€ * I : â„‚)â»Â¹ â€¢ âˆ® z in C(c, R), (z - w)â»Â¹ â€¢ f z` on the open
disc `Metric.ball c R`.

If `f' : â„‚ â†’ E` is a derivative of a complex differentiable function on the circle
`Metric.sphere c |R|`, then `âˆ® z in C(c, R), f' z = 0`.

fun {E} [NormedAddCommGroup E] [NormedSpace â„‚ E] [CompleteSpace E] {R} h0 {f} {c} {s} hs hc hd =>
  Or.casesOn (LE.le.eq_or_lt h0)
    (fun h =>
      Eq.ndrec (motive := fun {R} =>
        0 â‰¤ R â†’
          ContinuousOn f (Metric.closedBall c R) â†’
            (âˆ€ (z : â„‚), z âˆˆ Metric.ball c R \ s â†’ DifferentiableAt â„‚ f z) â†’ (âˆ® (z : â„‚) in C(c, R), f z) = 0)
        (fun h0 hc hd => circleIntegral.integral_radius_zero (fun z => f z) c) h h0 hc hd)
    fun h0 =>
    Trans.trans
      (Trans.trans (Eq.symm (circleIntegral.integral_sub_inv_smul_sub_smul (fun z => f z) c c R))
        (Complex.circleIntegral_sub_center_inv_smul_of_differentiable_on_off_countable h0 hs
          (ContinuousOn.smul (ContinuousOn.sub continuousOn_id continuousOn_const) hc) fun z hz =>
          DifferentiableAt.smul (DifferentiableAt.sub_const differentiableAt_id c) (hd z hz)))
      (Eq.mpr (id (sub_self c â–¸ Eq.refl ((2 * â†‘Real.pi * Complex.I) â€¢ (c - c) â€¢ f c = 0)))
        (Eq.mpr (id (zero_smul â„‚ (f c) â–¸ Eq.refl ((2 * â†‘Real.pi * Complex.I) â€¢ 0 â€¢ f c = 0)))
          (Eq.mpr (id (smul_zero (2 * â†‘Real.pi * Complex.I) â–¸ Eq.refl ((2 * â†‘Real.pi * Complex.I) â€¢ 0 = 0)))
            (Eq.refl 0))))
examples.name: Complex.circleIntegral_eq_zero_of_differentiable_on_off_countable
examples.doc:
**Cauchy-Goursat theorem** for a disk: if `f : â„‚ â†’ E` is continuous on a closed disk
`{z | â€–z - câ€– â‰¤ R}` and is complex differentiable at all but countably many points of its interior,
then the integral $\oint_{|z-c|=R}f(z)\,dz$ equals zero.

fun src tgt f => do
  let srcFields â† f src
  let tgtFields â† f tgt
  let __do_jp : PUnit.{1} â†’ Lean.CoreM Unit := fun y => do
    let col := Array.zip srcFields tgtFields;
      forIn col PUnit.unit fun x r =>
        match x with
        | (srcField, tgtField) =>
          if (srcField != tgtField) = true then do
            ToAdditive.insertTranslation (src ++ srcField) (tgt ++ tgtField) true
            pure (ForInStep.yield PUnit.unit)
          else
            let cls := `to_additive;
            do
            let __do_lift â† Lean.isTracingEnabledFor cls
            if __do_lift = true then do
                Lean.addTrace cls
                    (Lean.toMessageData "Translation " ++ Lean.toMessageData (src ++ srcField) ++
                          Lean.toMessageData " â†¦ " ++
                        Lean.toMessageData (tgt ++ tgtField) ++
                      Lean.toMessageData " is automatic.")
                pure (ForInStep.yield PUnit.unit)
              else do
                pure PUnit.unit
                pure (ForInStep.yield PUnit.unit)
    pure PUnit.unit
  if (Array.size srcFields != Array.size tgtFields) = true then do
      let y â†
        Lean.throwError
            (Lean.toMessageData "Failed to map fields of " ++ Lean.toMessageData src ++ Lean.toMessageData ", " ++
                        Lean.toMessageData tgt ++
                      Lean.toMessageData " with " ++
                    Lean.toMessageData srcFields ++
                  Lean.toMessageData " â†¦ " ++
                Lean.toMessageData tgtFields ++
              Lean.toMessageData "")
      __do_jp y
    else do
      let y â† pure PUnit.unit
      __do_jp y

fun e => do
  let env â† Lean.getEnv
  let reorderFn : Lean.Name â†’ List (List â„•) := fun nm =>
    Option.getD (Lean.NameMapExtension.find? ToAdditive.reorderAttr env nm) []
  let eâ‚‚ â†
    Lean.Meta.transform e
        (fun e =>
          let e0 := Lean.Expr.getAppFn e;
          let es := Lean.Expr.getAppArgs e;
          let __discr := Lean.Expr.constName? e0;
          match __discr with
          | some e0n =>
            let reorder := reorderFn e0n;
            let __do_jp := fun y =>
              let needed_n := List.foldr Nat.max 0 (List.join reorder) + 1;
              if (decide (needed_n â‰¤ Array.size es) || Array.size es == 0) = true then pure Lean.TransformStep.continue
              else do
                let e' â† ToAdditive.etaExpandN (needed_n - Array.size es) e
                let cls : Lean.Name := `to_additive_detail
                let __do_lift â† Lean.isTracingEnabledFor cls
                let __do_jp : Unit â†’ Lean.MetaM Lean.TransformStep := fun y =>
                  pure (Lean.TransformStep.continue (some e'))
                if __do_lift = true then do
                    let y â†
                      Lean.addTrace cls
                          (Lean.toMessageData "expanded " ++ Lean.toMessageData e ++ Lean.toMessageData " to " ++
                              Lean.toMessageData e' ++
                            Lean.toMessageData "")
                    __do_jp y
                  else do
                    let y â† pure PUnit.unit
                    __do_jp y;
            if List.isEmpty reorder = true then pure Lean.TransformStep.continue
            else do
              let y â† pure PUnit.unit
              __do_jp y
          | x => pure Lean.TransformStep.continue)
        fun e => pure (Lean.TransformStep.done e)
  let __do_jp : Unit â†’ Lean.MetaM Lean.Expr := fun y => pure eâ‚‚
  if (e != eâ‚‚) = true then
      let cls := `to_additive_detail;
      do
      let __do_lift â† Lean.isTracingEnabledFor cls
      if __do_lift = true then do
          let y â†
            Lean.addTrace cls
                (Lean.toMessageData "expand:\nBefore: " ++ Lean.toMessageData e ++ Lean.toMessageData "\nAfter:  " ++
                    Lean.toMessageData eâ‚‚ ++
                  Lean.toMessageData "")
          __do_jp y
        else do
          let y â† pure PUnit.unit
          __do_jp y
    else do
      let y â† pure PUnit.unit
      __do_jp y

fun cfg src =>
  let __discr := src;
  match __discr with
  | Lean.Name.str pre s =>
    let cls := `to_additive_detail;
    do
    let __do_lift â† Lean.isTracingEnabledFor cls
    let __do_jp : Unit â†’ Lean.CoreM Lean.Name := fun y =>
      let tgt_auto := ToAdditive.guessName s;
      let depth := Lean.Name.getNumParts cfg.tgt;
      do
      let __do_lift â† Lean.getEnv
      let pre : Lean.Name := Lean.Name.mapPrefix (ToAdditive.findTranslation? __do_lift) pre
      match Lean.Name.splitAt pre (depth - 1) with
        | (pre1, pre2) =>
          let __do_jp := fun y =>
            let res := if (cfg.tgt == Lean.Name.anonymous) = true then Lean.Name.str pre tgt_auto else pre1 ++ cfg.tgt;
            let __do_jp := fun y =>
              let __do_jp := fun y => pure res;
              if (cfg.tgt != Lean.Name.anonymous) = true then
                let cls := `to_additive_detail;
                do
                let __do_lift â† Lean.isTracingEnabledFor cls
                if __do_lift = true then do
                    let y â†
                      Lean.addTrace cls
                          (Lean.toMessageData "The automatically generated name would be " ++
                              Lean.toMessageData (Lean.Name.str pre tgt_auto) ++
                            Lean.toMessageData "")
                    __do_jp y
                  else do
                    let y â† pure PUnit.unit
                    __do_jp y
              else do
                let y â† pure PUnit.unit
                __do_jp y;
            if (res == src && cfg.tgt != src) = true then do
              let y â†
                Lean.throwError
                    (Lean.toMessageData "to_additive: can't transport " ++ Lean.toMessageData src ++
                      Lean.toMessageData " to itself.")
              __do_jp y
            else do
              let y â† pure PUnit.unit
              __do_jp y;
          if (cfg.tgt == Lean.Name.str pre2 tgt_auto && !cfg.allowAutoName && cfg.tgt != src) = true then do
            let y â†
              Lean.Linter.logLintIf ToAdditive.linter.toAdditiveGenerateName cfg.ref
                  (Lean.toMessageData "to_additive correctly autogenerated target name for " ++
                              Lean.toMessageData src ++
                            Lean.toMessageData ". " ++
                          Lean.toMessageData "\n" ++
                        Lean.toMessageData "You may remove the explicit argument " ++
                      Lean.toMessageData cfg.tgt ++
                    Lean.toMessageData ".")
            __do_jp y
          else do
            let y â† pure PUnit.unit
            __do_jp y
    if __do_lift = true then do
        let y â†
          Lean.addTrace cls
              (Lean.toMessageData "The name " ++ Lean.toMessageData s ++ Lean.toMessageData " splits as " ++
                  Lean.toMessageData (String.splitCase s 0) ++
                Lean.toMessageData "")
        __do_jp y
      else do
        let y â† pure PUnit.unit
        __do_jp y
  | x =>
    Lean.throwError
      (Lean.toMessageData "to_additive: can't transport " ++ Lean.toMessageData src ++ Lean.toMessageData "")

examples.name: ContinuousAffineMap.toConstProdContinuousLinearMap
examples.doc:
The space of affine maps between two normed spaces is linearly isometric to the product of the
codomain with the space of linear maps, by taking the value of the affine map at `(0 : V)` and the
linear part.

    [TopologicalSpace Î²] {a} {f g} h hf hg hh h2h =>
  let_fun this :=

        (id

            Eq.refl (ContinuousAt (â†¿h âˆ˜ fun x => (x, f x / g x)) a)))

            (Eq.mpr

                (congrArg (Filter.Tendsto (â†¿h âˆ˜ fun x => (x, f x / g x)) (nhds a))
                  (congrArg nhds (congrArg (â†¿h) (congrArg (Prod.mk a) (div_zero (f a)))))))

examples.name: ContinuousAt.comp_div_cases
examples.doc:
The function `f x / g x` is discontinuous when `g x = 0`. However, under appropriate
conditions, `h x (f x / g x)` is still continuous.  The condition is that if `g a = 0` then `h x y`
must tend to `h a 0` when `x` tends to `a`, with no information about `y`. This is represented by
the `âŠ¤` filter.  Note: `tendsto_prod_top_iff` characterizes this convergence in uniform spaces.  See
also `Filter.prod_top` and `Filter.mem_prod_top`.

    (match (motive := (x : Turing.ToPartrec.Cont) â†’ Turing.ToPartrec.Cont.below x â†’ List â„• â†’. List â„•) x with
      | Turing.ToPartrec.Cont.halt => fun x => pure
      | Turing.ToPartrec.Cont.consâ‚ fs as k => fun x v => do
        let ns â† Turing.ToPartrec.Code.eval fs as
        PProd.fst x.fst (List.headI v :: ns)
      | Turing.ToPartrec.Cont.consâ‚‚ ns k => fun x v => PProd.fst x.fst (List.headI ns :: v)
      | Turing.ToPartrec.Cont.comp f k => fun x v => Turing.ToPartrec.Code.eval f v >>= x.fst.fst
      | Turing.ToPartrec.Cont.fix f k => fun x v =>
        if List.headI v = 0 then PProd.fst x.fst (List.tail v)

examples.term:
fun x =>
  Turing.ToPartrec.Code.brecOn x fun x f =>
    (match (motive := (x : Turing.ToPartrec.Code) â†’ Turing.ToPartrec.Code.below x â†’ List â„• â†’. List â„•) x with
      | Turing.ToPartrec.Code.zero' => fun x v => pure (0 :: v)
      | Turing.ToPartrec.Code.succ => fun x v => pure [Nat.succ (List.headI v)]
      | Turing.ToPartrec.Code.tail => fun x v => pure (List.tail v)
      | Turing.ToPartrec.Code.cons f fs => fun x v => do
        let n â† PProd.fst x.fst v
        let ns â† PProd.fst x.snd.fst v
        pure (List.headI n :: ns)
      | Turing.ToPartrec.Code.comp f g => fun x v => PProd.fst x.snd.fst v >>= x.fst.fst
      | Turing.ToPartrec.Code.case f g => fun x v =>
        Nat.rec (PProd.fst x.fst (List.tail v)) (fun y x_1 => PProd.fst x.snd.fst (y :: List.tail v)) (List.headI v)
      | Turing.ToPartrec.Code.fix f => fun x =>
        PFun.fix fun v =>
          Part.map (fun v => if List.headI v = 0 then Sum.inl (List.tail v) else Sum.inr (List.tail v))
            (PProd.fst x.fst v))
      f
examples.name: Turing.ToPartrec.Code.eval
examples.doc:
The semantics of the `Code` primitives, as partial functions `List â„• â†’. List â„•`. By convention
we functions that return a single result return a singleton `[n]`, or in some cases `n :: v` where
`v` will be ignored by a subsequent function.

* `zero'` appends a `0` to the input. That is, `zero' v = 0 :: v`.
* `succ` returns the successor of the head of the input, defaulting to zero if there is no head:
  * `succ [] = [1]`
  * `succ (n :: v) = [n + 1]`
* `tail` returns the tail of the input
  * `tail [] = []`
  * `tail (n :: v) = v`
* `cons f fs` calls `f` and `fs` on the input and conses the results:
  * `cons f fs v = (f v).head :: fs v`
* `comp f g` calls `f` on the output of `g`:
  * `comp f g v = f (g v)`
* `case f g` cases on the head of the input, calling `f` or `g` depending on whether it is zero or
  a successor (similar to `Nat.casesOn`).
  * `case f g [] = f []`
  * `case f g (0 :: v) = f v`
  * `case f g (n+1 :: v) = g (n :: v)`
* `fix f` calls `f` repeatedly, using the head of the result of `f` to decide whether to call `f`
  again or finish:
  * `fix f v = []` if `f v = []`
  * `fix f v = w` if `f v = 0 :: w`
  * `fix f v = fix f w` if `f v = n+1 :: w` (the exact value of `n` is discarded)

fun x =>
  Nat.Partrec.Code.brecOn x fun x f =>
    (match (motive := (x : Nat.Partrec.Code) â†’ Nat.Partrec.Code.below x â†’ â„• â†’. â„•) x with
      | Nat.Partrec.Code.zero => fun x => pure 0
      | Nat.Partrec.Code.succ => fun x => â†‘Nat.succ
      | Nat.Partrec.Code.left => fun x => â†‘fun n => (Nat.unpair n).fst
      | Nat.Partrec.Code.right => fun x => â†‘fun n => (Nat.unpair n).snd
      | Nat.Partrec.Code.pair cf cg => fun x n =>
        Seq.seq (Nat.pair <$> PProd.fst x.fst n) fun x_1 => PProd.fst x.snd.fst n
      | Nat.Partrec.Code.comp cf cg => fun x n => PProd.fst x.snd.fst n >>= x.fst.fst
      | Nat.Partrec.Code.prec cf cg => fun x =>
        Nat.unpaired fun a n =>
          Nat.rec (PProd.fst x.fst a)
            (fun y IH => do
              let i â† IH
              PProd.fst x.snd.fst (Nat.pair a (Nat.pair y i)))
            n
      | Nat.Partrec.Code.rfind' cf => fun x =>
        Nat.unpaired fun a m =>
          Part.map (fun x => x + m)
            (Nat.rfind fun n => (fun m => decide (m = 0)) <$> PProd.fst x.fst (Nat.pair a (n + m))))
      f
examples.name: Nat.Partrec.Code.eval
examples.doc:
The interpretation of a `Nat.Partrec.Code` as a partial function.
* `Nat.Partrec.Code.zero`: The constant zero function.
* `Nat.Partrec.Code.succ`: The successor function.
* `Nat.Partrec.Code.left`: Left unpairing of a pair of â„• (encoded by `Nat.pair`)
* `Nat.Partrec.Code.right`: Right unpairing of a pair of â„• (encoded by `Nat.pair`)
* `Nat.Partrec.Code.pair`: Pairs the outputs of argument codes using `Nat.pair`.
* `Nat.Partrec.Code.comp`: Composition of two argument codes.
* `Nat.Partrec.Code.prec`: Primitive recursion. Given an argument of the form `Nat.pair a n`:
  * If `n = 0`, returns `eval cf a`.
  * If `n = succ k`, returns `eval cg (pair a (pair k (eval (prec cf cg) (pair a k))))`
* `Nat.Partrec.Code.rfind'`: Minimization. For `f` an argument of the form `Nat.pair a m`,
  `rfind' f m` returns the least `a` such that `f a m = 0`, if one exists and `f b m` terminates
  for `b < a`

examples.doc:
The standard case of the layer cake formula / Cavalieri's principle / tail probability formula:

For a nonnegative function `f` on a sigma-finite measure space, the Lebesgue integral of `f` can
be written (roughly speaking) as: `âˆ«â» f âˆ‚Î¼ = âˆ«â» t in (0).. âˆž, Î¼ {Ï‰ | f(Ï‰) > t}`.

See `lintegral_eq_lintegral_meas_le` for a version with sets of the form `{Ï‰ | f(Ï‰) â‰¥ t}`
instead.

For a nonnegative function `f` on a sigma-finite measure space, the Lebesgue integral of `f` can
be written (roughly speaking) as: `âˆ«â» f^p âˆ‚Î¼ = p * âˆ«â» t in (0).. âˆž, t^(p-1) * Î¼ {Ï‰ | f(Ï‰) > t}`.

examples.name: lintegral_comp_eq_lintegral_meas_lt_mul
examples.doc:
The layer cake formula / Cavalieri's principle / tail probability formula:

Let `f` be a non-negative measurable function on a sigma-finite measure space. Let `G` be an
increasing absolutely continuous function on the positive real line, vanishing at the origin,
with derivative `G' = g`. Then the integral of the composition `G âˆ˜ f` can be written as
the integral over the positive real line of the "tail measures" `Î¼ {Ï‰ | f(Ï‰) > t}` of `f`
weighted by `g`.

Roughly speaking, the statement is: `âˆ«â» (G âˆ˜ f) âˆ‚Î¼ = âˆ«â» t in (0).. âˆž, g(t) * Î¼ {Ï‰ | f(Ï‰) > t}`.

See `lintegral_comp_eq_lintegral_meas_le_mul` for a version with sets of the form `{Ï‰ | f(Ï‰) â‰¥ t}`
instead.

              (congrArg (MeasureTheory.lintegral (MeasureTheory.Measure.restrict MeasureTheory.volume (Set.Ioi 0)))
                (funext fun t => mul_one (â†‘â†‘Î¼ {a | t â‰¤ f a}))))
            (Eq.mp
              (congrArg (Eq (âˆ«â» (Ï‰ : Î±), ENNReal.ofReal (âˆ« (t : â„) in 0 ..f Ï‰, 1) âˆ‚Î¼))
                (congrArg (MeasureTheory.lintegral (MeasureTheory.Measure.restrict MeasureTheory.volume (Set.Ioi 0)))
                  (funext fun t => congrArg (HMul.hMul (â†‘â†‘Î¼ {a | t â‰¤ f a})) ENNReal.ofReal_one)))
              key)) â–¸
        Eq.refl (âˆ«â» (Ï‰ : Î±), ENNReal.ofReal (f Ï‰) âˆ‚Î¼ = âˆ«â» (t : â„) in Set.Ioi 0, â†‘â†‘Î¼ {a | t â‰¤ f a})))
    ((fun {Î±} {x} Î¼ Î¼_1 e_Î¼ =>
        Eq.rec (motive := fun Î¼_2 e_Î¼ =>
          âˆ€ (f f_1 : Î± â†’ ENNReal), f = f_1 â†’ MeasureTheory.lintegral Î¼ f = MeasureTheory.lintegral Î¼_2 f_1)
          (fun f f_1 e_f => e_f â–¸ Eq.refl (MeasureTheory.lintegral Î¼ f)) e_Î¼)
      Î¼ Î¼ (Eq.refl Î¼) (fun Ï‰ => ENNReal.ofReal (f Ï‰)) (fun Ï‰ => ENNReal.ofReal (âˆ« (t : â„) in 0 ..f Ï‰, 1))
      (funext fun Ï‰ =>
        of_eq_true
          (Eq.trans
            (congrArg (Eq (ENNReal.ofReal (f Ï‰)))
              (congrArg ENNReal.ofReal
                (Eq.trans
                  (Eq.trans (intervalIntegral.integral_const 1) (congrFun (congrArg HSMul.hSMul (sub_zero (f Ï‰))) 1))
                  (mul_one (f Ï‰)))))
            (eq_self (ENNReal.ofReal (f Ï‰))))))

A non-unital ring hom `Î± â†’â‚™+* Î²` can equivalently be viewed as a non-unital ring hom
`Î±áµáµ’áµ– â†’+* Î²áµáµ’áµ–`. This is the action of the (fully faithful) `áµáµ’áµ–`-functor on morphisms.

The group of `AffineEquiv`s are equivalent to the group of units of `AffineMap`.

This is the affine version of `LinearMap.GeneralLinearGroup.generalLinearEquiv`.

        pure !Lean.Expr.isConstOf (Lean.Expr.appArg!' (Lean.ConstantInfo.type const)) `ProofWidgets.PanelWidgetProps

fun pkg => do

        (fun p =>

    throw

      __do_jp y
